J	Li, YF; Ngom, A				Li, Yifeng; Ngom, Alioune			Sparse representation approaches for the classification of high-dimensional biological data	BMC SYSTEMS BIOLOGY			English	Article							FACE RECOGNITION; CANCER	Background: High-throughput genomic and proteomic data have important applications in medicine including prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis of diseases, and molecular biology, for example pathway identification. Many of such applications can be formulated to classification and dimension reduction problems in machine learning. There are computationally challenging issues with regards to accurately classifying such data, and which due to dimensionality, noise and redundancy, to name a few. The principle of sparse representation has been applied to analyzing high-dimensional biological data within the frameworks of clustering, classification, and dimension reduction approaches. However, the existing sparse representation methods are inefficient. The kernel extensions are not well addressed either. Moreover, the sparse representation techniques have not been comprehensively studied yet in bioinformatics. Results: In this paper, a Bayesian treatment is presented on sparse representations. Various sparse coding and dictionary learning models are discussed. We propose fast parallel active-set optimization algorithm for each model. Kernel versions are devised based on their dimension-free property. These models are applied for classifying high-dimensional biological data. Conclusions: In our experiment, we compared our models with other methods on both accuracy and computing time. It is shown that our models can achieve satisfactory accuracy, and their performance are very efficient.	[Li, Yifeng; Ngom, Alioune] Univ Windsor, Sch Comp Sci, Windsor, ON N9B 3P4, Canada	Li, YF (reprint author), Univ Windsor, Sch Comp Sci, Windsor, ON N9B 3P4, Canada.	li11112c@uwindsor.ca			Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) [RGPIN228117-2011]; IEEE CIS Walter Karplus Summer Research Grant; Ontario Graduate Scholarship	This article is based on "Fast Sparse Representation Approaches for the Classification of High-Dimensional Biological Data", by Yifeng Li and Alioune Ngom which appeared in Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM), 2012 IEEE International Conference on. J	Liu, LL; Zhang, ZJ; Mei, Q; Chen, M				Liu, Lili; Zhang, Zijun; Mei, Qian; Chen, Ming			PSI: A Comprehensive and Integrative Approach for Accurate Plant Subcellular Localization Prediction	PLOS ONE			English	Article							TERMINAL TARGETING SEQUENCES; MITOCHONDRIAL PROTEINS; EUKARYOTIC PROTEINS; GENE ONTOLOGY; WEB SERVER; LOCATION; DATABASE; TOOL	Predicting the subcellular localization of proteins conquers the major drawbacks of high-throughput localization experiments that are costly and time-consuming. However, current subcellular localization predictors are limited in scope and accuracy. In particular, most predictors perform well on certain locations or with certain data sets while poorly on others. Here, we present PSI, a novel high accuracy web server for plant subcellular localization prediction. PSI derives the wisdom of multiple specialized predictors via a joint-approach of group decision making strategy and machine learning methods to give an integrated best result. The overall accuracy obtained (up to 93.4%) was higher than best individual (CELLO) by similar to 10.7%. The precision of each predicable subcellular location (more than 80%) far exceeds that of the individual predictors. It can also deal with multi-localization proteins. PSI is expected to be a powerful tool in protein location engineering as well as in plant sciences, while the strategy employed could be applied to other integrative problems. A user-friendly web server, PSI, has been developed for free access at http://bis.zju.edu.cn/psi/.	[Liu, Lili; Zhang, Zijun; Mei, Qian; Chen, Ming] Zhejiang Univ, Coll Life Sci, Hangzhou 310003, Zhejiang, Peoples R China	Chen, M (reprint author), Zhejiang Univ, Coll Life Sci, Hangzhou 310003, Zhejiang, Peoples R China.	mchen@zju.edu.cn			National Natural Sciences Foundation of China [30771326, 30971743]; Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University of China [NCET-07-0740]	This work was supported by the National Natural Sciences Foundation of China [30771326, 30971743], the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University of China [NCET-07-0740]. J	Mason, MR; Nagaraja, HN; Camerlengo, T; Joshi, V; Kumar, PS				Mason, Matthew R.; Nagaraja, Haikady N.; Camerlengo, Terry; Joshi, Vinayak; Kumar, Purnima S.			Deep Sequencing Identifies Ethnicity-Specific Bacterial Signatures in the Oral Microbiome	PLOS ONE			English	Article							SQUAMOUS-CELL CARCINOMA; DIFFERENT RACIAL GROUPS; POLYMORPHISMS; PERIODONTITIS; PREVALENCE; HEAD	Oral infections have a strong ethnic predilection; suggesting that ethnicity is a critical determinant of oral microbial colonization. Dental plaque and saliva samples from 192 subjects belonging to four major ethnicities in the United States were analyzed using terminal restriction fragment length polymorphism (t-RFLP) and 16S pyrosequencing. Ethnicity-specific clustering of microbial communities was apparent in saliva and subgingival biofilms, and a machine-learning classifier was capable of identifying an individual's ethnicity from subgingival microbial signatures. The classifier identified African Americans with a 100% sensitivity and 74% specificity and Caucasians with a 50% sensitivity and 91% specificity. The data demonstrates a significant association between ethnic affiliation and the composition of the oral microbiome; to the extent that these microbial signatures appear to be capable of discriminating between ethnicities. J	Shrivastava, NA; Panigrahi, BK				Shrivastava, Nitin Anand; Panigrahi, Bijaya Ketan			Point and prediction interval estimation for electricity markets with machine learning techniques and wavelet transforms	NEUROCOMPUTING			English	Article						Artificial neural network (ANN); Bootstraps; Extreme learning machine (ELM); Prediction intervals; Wavelet transforms; Uncertainty	ARTIFICIAL NEURAL-NETWORKS; CLEARING PRICE PREDICTION; FEEDFORWARD NETWORKS; CONFIDENCE; MODELS; COMPRESSION	A growing number of countries all over the world are switching over to deregulated or the market structure of electricity sector with a view to enhance productivity, efficiency and to lower the prices. Barring a few cases, the deregulated structure is doing quite well in most of the countries. However a persistent issue that plagues the involved parties such as producers, traders, retailers etc., is the uncertainty that prevails in the system. Due to a number of known, unknown factors, the electricity prices exhibit fluctuating characteristics which is difficult to control as well as predict. Several forecasting techniques have been developed and successfully implemented for existing markets around the world with comparable performance. However, the uncertainty aspect of the point forecasts has not been analyzed significantly. In this work, an attempt is made to quantify such uncertainties existing in the market using statistical techniques like prediction intervals. Hybrid models using neural networks and Extreme Learning machines with wavelets as preprocessors are developed and applied for point as well as prediction interval forecasting for Ontario Electricity Market, PJM Day-Ahead and Real time markets. (C) 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.	[Shrivastava, Nitin Anand; Panigrahi, Bijaya Ketan] Indian Inst Technol Delhi, Dept Elect Engn, New Delhi, India	Shrivastava, NA (reprint author), Indian Inst Technol Delhi, Dept Elect Engn, New Delhi, India.	anandnitin26@gmail.com; bijayaketan.panigrahi@gmail.com	Panigrahi, Bijaya Ketan/G-1005-2010				Amjady N., 2006, IEEE Power & Energy Magazine, V4, DOI 10.1109/MPAE.2006.1597990; Amjady N, 2006, IEEE T POWER SYST, V21, P887, DOI 10.1109/TPWRS.2006.873409; Benoit DF, 2009, EXPERT SYST APPL, V36, P10475, DOI 10.1016/j.eswa.2009.01.031; Bishop M., 1996, NEURAL NETWORKS PATT; Boix M, 2010, MATH COMPUT MODEL, V52, P1265, DOI 10.1016/j.mcm.2010.02.019; Box G.E.P., 1990, TIME SERIES ANAL FOR; Cao R, 1997, COMMUN STAT-SIMUL C, V26, P961, DOI 10.1080/03610919708813420; Claudia P., 2004, IEEE T POWER SYST, V19, P366; Conejo AJ, 2005, IEEE T POWER SYST, V20, P1035, DOI 10.1109/TPWRS.2005.846054; Davison A. J	Vrtaric, D; Ceperic, V; Baric, A				Vrtaric, D.; Ceperic, V.; Baric, A.			Area-efficient differential Gaussian circuit for dedicated hardware implementations of Gaussian function based machine learning algorithms	NEUROCOMPUTING			English	Article						Gaussian function; Gaussian circuit; Machine learning hardware	ARTIFICIAL BRAIN PROJECTS; SUPPORT VECTOR MACHINE; NEURAL-NETWORKS; WORLD SURVEY; ANALOG; SIMULATIONS	A simple and area-efficient differential Gaussian circuit is presented for machine learning dedicated hardware implementations, where Gaussian functions are needed, e.g. for artificial neural networks (as transfer function), support vector machines (as kernel function) and fuzzy logic (as membership function). The proposed Gaussian circuit consists of only 4 transistors. Simulations in the 0.18-mu m CMOS UMC technology show that the proposed circuit is more accurate, less susceptible to the process variations and requires less on-chip area when compared to state-of-the-art. (C) 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.	[Vrtaric, D.; Ceperic, V.; Baric, A.] Univ Zagreb, Fac Elect Engn & Comp, Zagreb 10000, Croatia; [Ceperic, V.] Katholieke Univ Leuven, Dept Electromech Engn, Louvain, Belgium	Ceperic, V (reprint author), Univ Zagreb, Fac Elect Engn & Comp, Unska 3, Zagreb 10000, Croatia.	vladimir.ceperic@ieee.org					Anguita D, 2003, NEUROCOMPUTING, V55, P265, DOI 10.1016/S0925-2312(03)00382-5; Bailey JA, 2011, NEUROCOMPUTING, V74, P2392, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2011.04.001; Chakrabartty S, 2007, IEEE J SOLID-ST CIRC, V42, P1169, DOI 10.1109/JSSC.2007.894803; de Garis H, 2010, NEUROCOMPUTING, V74, P3, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2010.08.004; Eickhoff R, 2007, NEUROCOMPUTING, V70, P2758, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2006.04.012; Genov R, 2003, IEEE T NEURAL NETWOR, V14, P1426, DOI 10.1109/TNN.2003.816345; Goertzel B, 2010, NEUROCOMPUTING, V74, P30, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2010.08.012; Kang K, 2010, IEEE T CIRCUITS-I, V57, P1513, DOI 10.1109/TCSI.2009.2034234; Kecman Vojislav, 2001, LEARNING SOFT COMPUT; Lau KT, 1997, INT J ELECTRON, V83, P91, DOI 10.1080/002072197135689; Li Fei, 2010, 2010 AS PAC C POSTGR, P198, DOI 10.1109/PRIMEASIA.2010.5604926; Madrenas J, 1996, IEEE T CIRCUITS-II, V43, P70, DOI 10.1109/82.481479; Misra J, 2010, NEUROCOMPUTING, V74, P239, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2010.03.021; Peng S.-Y., 2007, IFIP INT C VER LARG, P13; Zou Q, 2006, NEUROCOMPUTING, V69, P1137, DOI 10.1016/j.neucom.2005.12.061	15	0	0	ELSEVIER SCIENCE BV	AMSTERDAM	PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS	0925-2312		NEUROCOMPUTING	Neurocomputing	OCT 22	2013	118						329	333		10.1016/j.neucom.2013.02.022		5	Computer Science, Artificial Intelligence	Computer Science	208QH	WOS:000323693700034	
J	Jung, KH; Lee, J				Jung, Kyu-Hwan; Lee, Jaewook			Probabilistic generative ranking method based on multi-support vector domain description	INFORMATION SCIENCES			English	Article						Learning to rank; Classification Support vector machines; Support vector domain description; Kernel method; Information retrieval	CLASSIFICATION; REGRESSION	As the volume of database grows, retrieval and ordering of information according to relevance has become an important and challenging task. Ranking problem has recently been considered and formulated as a machine learning problem. Among the various learning-torank methods, the ranking support vector machines (SVMs) have been widely applied in various applications because of its state-of-the-art performance. In this paper, we propose a novel ranking method based on a probabilistic generative model approach. The proposed method utilizes multi-support vector domain description (multi-SVDD) and constructs pseudo-conditional probabilities for data pairs, thus enabling the construction of an efficient posterior probability function of relevance judgment of data pairs. Results of experiments on both synthetic and real large-scale datasets show that the proposed method can efficiently learn ranking functions better than ranking SVMs. (C) 2013 Published by Elsevier Inc.	[Jung, Kyu-Hwan] SK Planet, Dept Platform Technol, Seoul, South Korea; [Lee, Jaewook] Seoul Natl Univ, Dept Ind Engn, Seoul, South Korea	Lee, J (reprint author), Seoul Natl Univ, Dept Ind Engn, Seoul, South Korea.	jaewook@seoul.ac.kr			National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF); Korean government (MEST) [2011-0017657]	This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) Grant funded by the Korean government (MEST) (No. 2011-0017657).
